William Shakespeare, often hailed as the greatest writer in the English language, has had a profound impact on modern literature. His works, including plays, sonnets, and narrative poems, have been translated into every major living language. Shakespeare introduced over 1,700 words to the English language, many of which we still use today. Moreover, his exploration of universal themes such as love, betrayal, and ambition continues to resonate with contemporary audiences. How did Shakespeare primarily influence modern literature?

A. By promoting the use of iambic pentameter
B. By introducing tragicomedy as a new genre
C. Through his critique of Elizabethan society
D. By enriching the English language and exploring universal themes
E. None of the above

D. By enriching the English language and exploring universal themes

While all the options have some connection to Shakespeare's work, option D most accurately captures his primary influence on modern literature. Shakespeare's contribution to the English language is immense; he coined numerous phrases and words that are still in use today. His plays delve into universal themes that transcend time and culture, making his works relevant even in the modern era. While iambic pentameter was a common meter in his time, and he did write tragicomedies, his broader impact lies in language enrichment and thematic depth.
